articles.headline: Pentagon Gives Boeing New Chance at Contract
articles.snippet: A multibillion-dollar contract for refueling tankers will be reopened after a report found flaws in the original process.
articles.abstract: A multibillion-dollar contract for refueling tankers will be reopened after a report found flaws in the original process.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon announced on Wednesday that it would reopen bidding on a $35 billion contract for midair refueling tankers, allowing Boeing to continue its effort to wrest the business from a partnership of Northrop Grumman and the European parent of its rival Airbus.

articles.headline: Using Star Power to Repair Nigeria’s Image
articles.snippet: Nduka Obaigbena, a Nigerian media mogul — part Bono, part Diddy — has been challenging his country’s often brutal kleptocracy for decades.
articles.abstract: Nduka Obaigbena, a Nigerian media mogul — part Bono, part Diddy — has been challenging his country’s often brutal kleptocracy for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria  It’s hard to rehabilitate a country  especially Nigeria, best known these days for violence in the oil-producing Niger Delta.

articles.headline: Foreign Investors Pile Up More Pieces of Americana
articles.snippet: The global commodities boom and the dollar’s decline have unleashed a wave of big money buys of prized American assets by newly flush foreign investors.
articles.abstract: The global commodities boom and the dollar’s decline have unleashed a wave of big money buys of prized American assets by newly flush foreign investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hunt for the great American trophy asset is on.

articles.headline: Cutting Out the Middlemen, Shoppers Buy Slices of Farms
articles.snippet: A growing number of people are skipping out on grocery stores and instead going right to the source by buying shares of farms — in essence hiring personal farmers.
articles.abstract: A growing number of people are skipping out on grocery stores and instead going right to the source by buying shares of farms — in essence hiring personal farmers.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMPTON TOWNSHIP, Ill.  In an environmentally conscious tweak on the typical way of getting food to the table, growing numbers of people are skipping out on grocery stores and even farmers markets and instead going right to the source by buying shares of farms.

articles.headline: Wachovia Hires a Treasury Insider to Lift It Out of Its Banking Woes
articles.snippet: Robert K. Steel, the under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, has been chosen to be Wachovia’s new chief executive.
articles.abstract: Robert K. Steel, the under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, has been chosen to be Wachovia’s new chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his perch inside the Treasury Department, Robert K. Steel has wrestled with the troubles plaguing America’s financial industry. Now he will confront those problems up close at the Wachovia Corporation, one of the nation’s largest banks.

articles.headline: Small Business Is Latest Focus in Health Fight
articles.snippet: States are taking various approaches to help businesses unable to provide health insurance for their employees.
articles.abstract: States are taking various approaches to help businesses unable to provide health insurance for their employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the number of people without health insurance continues to rise, many states and Congress have begun to focus on one of the biggest causes: the growing number of small business owners and their workers who are unable to afford coverage.

articles.headline: Sharp Fall for Stocks Amid Angst in Lending
articles.snippet: Widespread fear about the health of the mortgage industry took hold Wednesday afternoon, and investors could not shake the jitters.
articles.abstract: Widespread fear about the health of the mortgage industry took hold Wednesday afternoon, and investors could not shake the jitters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Half an hour was all it took for a dreary day on Wall Street to turn dire.

articles.headline: Militant Gains in Pakistan Said to Draw Fighters
articles.snippet: An increase in the number of foreign fighters may reflect a change that is making Pakistan’s tribal areas the preferred destination for some Sunni insurgents.
articles.abstract: An increase in the number of foreign fighters may reflect a change that is making Pakistan’s tribal areas the preferred destination for some Sunni insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  American military and intelligence officials say there has been an increase in recent months in the number of foreign fighters who have traveled to Pakistan’s tribal areas to join with militants there.
